Utterance: Hi! Welcome back. How have you been since our last session?
Hi Ellie! I’ve been trying to practice mindfulness, like we discussed. It’s been a bit of a challenge, but I’m getting there.
That’s great to hear! What has been the most challenging part for you?
I think it’s just remembering to take those moments for myself. I get so caught up in work and other responsibilities.
That’s completely understandable. It can be easy to prioritize everything else over self-care. Have you found any particular times or situations where it’s easier to practice mindfulness?
I’ve noticed that I can do it during my breaks at work. It helps me reset a bit.
That’s fantastic! Taking those small breaks can really make a difference. Have you noticed any changes in your stress levels since you started practicing?
I think so. I feel a bit less overwhelmed when I take those moments to breathe.
That’s wonderful progress! Let’s build on that. How about setting a specific time each day for mindfulness, even if it’s just for a few minutes?
I could try that. Maybe in the morning before I start my day?
That sounds like a perfect plan! Establishing a routine can help reinforce the habit. How do you feel about journaling your experiences as well?
I’ve started journaling! It’s been nice to get my thoughts out on paper.
That’s excellent! What have you been writing about?
Mostly about my feelings regarding work and my daughter. It helps me see things more clearly.
That’s a great way to reflect. Have you noticed any patterns or recurring themes in what you’re writing?
Yes, I keep coming back to my worries about being a good parent and my anxiety about work.
It’s important to acknowledge those feelings. Would you like to explore those concerns further today?
Yes, I think I need to. I want to be a supportive parent, but sometimes I feel like I’m not doing enough.
It’s common for parents to feel that way. What does “doing enough” look like for you?
I guess being emotionally available and supportive. I just don’t want to overstep or make her feel like I’m judging her.
That’s a valid concern. Have you considered asking her directly what kind of support she needs from you?
I haven’t, but it sounds like a good idea. I just worry I’ll come off as overbearing.
Open communication is key. By asking her what she needs, you’re showing that you care and want to support her in a way that feels comfortable for her.
You’re right. I’ll try to have that conversation soon.
I’m glad to hear that! It can be a great way to strengthen your relationship. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss regarding your work anxiety?
I’ve been feeling a bit overwhelmed with deadlines and expectations. I worry that I won’t meet them.
That’s a common feeling in high-pressure environments. Have you thought about how you can break down your tasks to make them feel more manageable?
I haven’t really tried that. I usually just dive in and hope for the best.
Breaking tasks into smaller, more achievable steps can help reduce anxiety. You could create a to-do list and prioritize what needs to be done first.
That sounds helpful. I’ll give it a shot.
Great! Remember to celebrate small victories as you complete tasks. It can help boost your confidence.
I’ll try to remember that. I tend to overlook my accomplishments.
It’s easy to do, but acknowledging your progress is important for your mental well-being. Is there anything else you’d like to cover today?
No, I think we’ve covered a lot. Thank you for your support.
You’re very welcome! I’m proud of the progress you’re making. I look forward to hearing about your experiences in our next session. Take care!
Thanks, Ellie! I’ll see you next time.
